importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and development timeline of the Reefline project, which is progressing into its initial phase.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with initial construction beginning in 2025 and full realization anticipated by 2035.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a seven-mile-long artificial reef project off Miami Beach designed to restore the island’s lost coral reef habitat.
The project combines art and science, featuring underwater sculptures made from marine-grade concrete that will host and be colonized by resilient soft corals such as gorgonians.
The reef will be accessible to swimmers within 15–20 feet of the coast, without requiring a boat, making it a public ecotourism and educational attraction.
Coral nursery operations led by Colin Foord at a warehouse in Miami are critical to growing and preparing corals for transplantation.
Artistic director Ximena Caminos, originally from Argentina, is a cultural placemaker who uses art to revitalize communities and is leading the project’s vision and fundraising.
The project includes 22 cast concrete cars arranged in an underwater traffic jam, which act as coral habitats due to their structural design.
Artist Leandro Ehrlich contributes to the project, believing that over time, corals will cover and transform the sculptures, making them disappear.
Reefline aims to restore a historic coral reef that once existed off Miami Beach but was buried by sand in the 1970s.
The project is funded by a $5 million Miami Beach city bond and requires an additional $6 million in private fundraising for its first phase.
A marine learning center will be established on land to educate visitors about coral reef conservation and climate change.
Future phases may include a constellation of 57 giant starfish sculptures, which could one day symbolize the city of Miami Beach.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a seven-mile-long artificial reef designed to restore a historic coral reef that was lost in the 1970s. The initiative combines art and marine science, featuring underwater sculptures—such as concrete cars and starfish—designed to support the growth of resilient corals like gorgonians. Led by artist and cultural placemaker Ximena Caminos and coral scientist Colin Foord, the project includes a coral nursery, public access for swimmers, and an onshore marine learning center to educate the public. Funded by a $5 million city bond and seeking an additional $6 million in private funds, the first phase will begin this month and is expected to take at least a decade to complete. Over time, the sculptures will be colonized by coral, transforming into vibrant underwater ecosystems and potentially becoming symbolic landmarks for Miami Beach.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
